G.L. c. 218 \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218 § 19, as this case involves claims for damages within the jurisdictional limit of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223 \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223 § 1, because the Defendant operates its business in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the incident occurred there.

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.raw_text: *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 742 (1995) (defining duty of care to prevent foreseeable harm)
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Defendant had a duty to exercise reasonable care in supervising children participating in its after-school programs to ensure their safety and prevent injury.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landowner’s duty regarding a state highway adjacent to its premises, not a duty to supervise children in an after‑school program. The court discusses general negligence and landowner duties, as well as voluntarily assumed duties, but it ultimately holds that the defendant owed no duty to provide additional safety measures beyond hiring police. It does not address or establish any rule about supervising children in organized programs, so using it to support that specific duty of care is inaccurate.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. … It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land… The mere fact that Westwood’s facilities used land on both sides of Route 1A… does not necessarily impose on it the broad duty to provide safe passage…”

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.proposition: Defendant had a duty to exercise reasonable care in supervising children participating in its after-school programs to ensure their safety and prevent injury.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a hospital owed a duty to an unrelated police officer to control or detain a sedated adult patient; it does not involve children, after-school programs, or supervision duties in that context. The court explicitly holds that the hospital owed no duty to the third-party officer and rejects expanding special-relationship duties beyond narrow, defined categories. Thus, the opinion does not establish or affirm a duty to exercise reasonable care in supervising children in after-school programs and in fact limits third-party duty theories instead of supporting them.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: “We have not previously recognized, and do not now recognize, a duty to a third person of a medical professional to control a patient (excluding a patient of a mental health professional, see note 10, supra) arising from any claimed special relationship between the medical professional and the patient. … The hospital owed no duty to Leavitt to control or detain the patient.”

*Coughlin v. Pitman*, 337 Mass. 96, 99 (.proposition: Defendant’s duty included maintaining adequate staff-to-child ratios, staying attentive to children’s activities, and intervening to prevent foreseeable dangers, including rough and unsafe play.
*Coughlin v. Pitman*, 337 Mass. 96, 99 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns compliance of a conditional sale agreement with Massachusetts consumer credit statutes and the legality of an attorney’s fee provision in a finance contract. It does not involve childcare, supervision of children, staffing ratios, or any duty to prevent rough or unsafe play. The proposition about a defendant’s duty in supervising children is unrelated to the contractual and statutory issues decided in this case, so the citation does not support that proposition.
*Coughlin v. Pitman*, 337 Mass. 96, 99 (.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff seeks declaratory relief against Powered Equipment Corp. and Atlantic Corporation, a finance company, with respect to a conditional sale agreement by which the plaintiff purchased from Equipment a machine known as a crawler back-hoe for $12,000... The plaintiff alleges that the agreement does not comply with G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 255, § 12... and § 13A... in that (a) it fails to set forth certain provisions... and (b) it sets forth... a provision that... the buyer... shall pay an additional sum equal to fifteen per cent of the aggregate of principal and interest unpaid at the time of the employment of such attorney.

*Butler v. Jordan*, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 11.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that the failure to properly supervise children in a gym environment, where rough play could lead to serious injuries, created a foreseeable risk of harm.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (200.raw_text: *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006) (foreseeability of harm is central to negligence)
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (200.proposition: A.J.’s injuries were a foreseeable and direct result of Defendant’s negligent actions and omissions.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (200.support_reasoning: The case supports the broader principle that foreseeability of harm is central to duty and negligence, but it does not support the specific, fact-bound assertion that A.J.’s injuries were a foreseeable and direct result of a particular defendant’s conduct. Jupin v. Kask holds that it was foreseeable that a mentally unstable person with unfettered access to a home with unsecured guns might steal a gun and commit violent crime, and that this supported recognizing a duty; it does not adjudicate causation or foreseeability for ‘A.J.’s’ injuries, who is not part of this case. Thus the opinion can be cited for the general foreseeability/duty principle, not as authority that A.J.’s injuries in another matter were foreseeable and directly caused by that defendant’s negligence.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (200.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’… A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor… Consequently… ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … [T]he risk in the instant case … was both foreseeable and foreseen.”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, A.J. sustained a concussion, pain and suffering, and required medical treatment, resulting in damages to Plaintiff.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns factual, causation-and-damages allegations in a routine negligence personal injury claim (concussion, pain and suffering, medical treatment). Payton v. Abbott Labs is a DES class action addressing complex issues of emotional distress without physical harm, wrongful life, prenatal injury, and market-share liability, not the basic standard that a plaintiff may recover for concussion and related damages proximately caused by negligence. The opinion nowhere discusses or establishes a rule about concussions or the specific type of damages described, so it does not support that proposition.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress.... In summary, we hold that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causation; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case."

*Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 409.proposition: Plaintiff has incurred $5,000 in medical expenses and continues to suffer damages stemming from the Defendant’s negligent supervision.
*Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 409.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any specific dollar amount of medical expenses, nor does it make any finding about continuing damages or negligent supervision. Instead, it addresses liability standards under the child trespasser statute, comparative negligence, and procedural issues about amending the complaint. Thus, the case cannot be used as authority for the factual proposition that the plaintiff incurred $5,000 in medical expenses and continues to suffer damages from negligent supervision.
*Mathis v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 409.relevant_excerpt: The jury found that MEC violated its duty toward foreseeable child trespassers under G. L. c. 231, § 85Q (1988 ed.). The jury also found that the plaintiff was comparatively negligent. The jury determined that the plaintiff was 75% at fault, while MEC was 25% at fault. Thus, the plaintiff was barred, under the comparative negligence statute, G. L. c. 231, § 85 (1988 ed.), from recovering any damages from MEC.
